"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Congress finds that the United States has had persistent trade deficits since 1978, with significant deficits with countries like China, the European Union, and Japan in 2009. The trade balance improved in 2009 due to reduced demand for imports, not increased exports. In 2009, the United States had trade deficits with China, the European Union, and Japan. Despite an overall decline in the trade deficit, China accounted for 44 percent of the merchandise trade deficit. The United States faces significant trade barriers with its trading partners, and recommendations are needed to address structural imbalances in the trade deficit. SEC. 2. ESTABLISHMENT OF COMMISSION. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission is established with 11 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders to represent labor, small businesses, and manufacturing interests. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission is established with 11 members appointed by various Senate and House leaders to represent different interests. The Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives establishes qualifications for members, limiting presidential appointments to one executive branch official and requiring expertise in various fields for other appointments. Members must not be officers or employees of the United States. The Commission members in the United States should represent diverse economic perspectives and offer new insights into the trade deficit. Appointments are for the life of the Commission, made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission members in the United States should represent diverse economic perspectives and offer new insights into the trade deficit. Appointments are for the life of the Commission, made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings are called by the Chairperson. The members elect a chairperson and vice chairperson, and a majority constitutes a quorum for business transactions. Each member has one vote of equal value. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with examining the causes of the US trade deficit and providing recommendations to reduce trade imbalances. This includes analyzing macroeconomic factors like currency practices and foreign government purchases of US assets. The Commission is responsible for assessing trade deficits with countries that have significant barriers to market access, investment requirements, and non-compliance with labor standards impacting competition and consumer choices. The Commission will analyze the impact of free trade agreements on the US trade deficit, as well as the effects of investment flows in and out of the country on the deficit. This includes examining differences in environmental protection, enforcement of laws, and policies that support manufacturers in other countries. The Commission will analyze the impact of free trade agreements on the US trade deficit, including the effects of outbound investment, relocation of production facilities overseas, foreign direct investment in the US, and bilateral trade agreements. The Commission will examine the impact of free trade agreements, outbound investment, relocation of production facilities overseas, foreign direct investment, and bilateral trade agreements on the US trade deficit. Additionally, it will assess the role of imports of oil and energy products, and how US foreign policy influences economic and trade policies. The consequences of the trade deficit on the domestic economy, manufacturing capacity, job quality, and quantity will also be identified and quantified. The Commission will assess the impact of trade deficits on manufacturing capacity, job quality, wages, and standards. It will also evaluate the effects of trade deficits on defense production, innovation capabilities, and economic growth in the United States. Recommendations will include strategies for improving trade balances and utilizing trade policy tools more effectively. The curr_chunk focuses on enhancing competitiveness of US manufacturers, improving coordination of Federal departments related to trade, and enhancing trade data collection and reporting. The Commission is required to submit a report containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative and legislative actions within 16 months of the Act's enactment. Members can also submit additional views. The Commission established by the Act has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Commission is authorized to submit a report with findings and recommendations within 16 months of the Act's enactment. The Commission members, excluding federal officers or employees, receive compensation based on the Executive Schedule level IV rate for each day of duty. Officers or employees of the US government serve without additional compensation. Members are also entitled to travel expenses at authorized rates while away from home. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairperson can also determine their compensation without adhering to specific pay rate regulations. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel with pay rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Commission to carry out the Act and a requirement for a GAO audit of the Commission's financial books and records within 6 months of termination. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report.
